case_name: Special Leave Petition Civil No. 890 of 1964

facts.text: Special Leave Petition (Civil) No. 890 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Special Leave Petition  Civil  No. 890 of 1964. Petiti

facts.text: Petition for special leave to appeal from judgment and decree dated December 16, 1963 of Rajasthan High Court in Civil First Appeal No. 54 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Petition for special leave to appeal to the Supreme Court from the judgment and decree dated December 16, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil First Appeal No., 54 of 1956.

facts.text: Petitioner applies for special leave to appeal under Article 136 against Rajasthan High Court judgment dated December 16, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner applies for special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution, against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan dated December 16, 1963 in Civil First Appeal No. 54 of 1956 on two grounds

facts.text: Petitioner commenced suit on July 2, 1951 in Court of Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer against respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companymenced on July 2, 1951 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer an action against the respondents claiming a decree for Rs. 10,665 and for rendition of accounts

facts.text: Petitioner claimed decree for Rs. 10,665 and rendition of accounts for balance of sale proceeds of 104 bales of cotton.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companymenced on July 2, 1951 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer an action against the respondents claiming a decree for Rs. 10,665 and for rendition of accounts in respect of the balance of sale proceeds of 104 bales of companyton

facts.text: 104 bales of cotton purchased by petitioner through agency of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: purchased by him through the agency of the respondents. The petitioner claimed that 104 bales of companyton purchased by him were sold by the respondents as his agents on May 14, 1948

facts.text: 104 bales of cotton sold by respondents as agents on May 14, 1948 for Rs. 27,267/13/6.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claimed that 104 bales of companyton purchased by him were sold by the respondents as his agents on May 14, 1948 for Rs. 27,267/13/6 and without settling the account the respondents delivered

facts.text: Respondents delivered demand draft for Rs. 11,000 which was encashed.

anchor.surface_text: and without settling the account the respondents delivered towards that amount a demand draft for Rs. 11,000 which was encashed and four cheques of the aggregate value of Rs. 13,000

facts.text: Four cheques of aggregate Rs. 13,000 not encashed due to lack of arrangement with respondents' bankers.

anchor.surface_text: which was encashed and four cheques of the aggregate value of Rs. 13,000 which because of lack of arrangement with the respondents bankers were number encashed

facts.text: Petitioner entitled to Rs. 10,665 being amount due on dishonoured cheques and interest at 6% per annum from July 2, 1947 to July 1, 1951, less Rs. 4,000 subsequently received.

anchor.surface_text: and the petitioner on that account was entitled to receive from the respondents Rs. 10,665 being the amount due on the foot of dishonoured cheques and interest thereon at the rate of 6 per annum between July 2, 1947 to July 1, 1951, less Rs. 4,000 subsequently received by him.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed decree for balance of price after credits for commission, dalali and godown charges.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also claimed a decree for the balance of the price. after giving credit for companymission, dalali and godown charges incurred by the respondents as his agents

facts.text: Trial Court passed decree directing accounts for 104 bales and appointed Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court passed a decree directing that account be taken for ascertaining the amount due in respect of the entire transaction of 104 bales and for taking accounts appointed a Commissioner.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court reversed trial court decree and dismissed suit, holding transactions of unregistered firm constituted by petitioner and Duli Chand, suit barred.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Rajasthan reversed the decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the suit, holding that the transactions in respect of which the claim was made by the petitioner were those of an unregistered firm companystituted by the petitioner and another person named Duli Chand and the suit was barred because the firm was number registered.

facts.text: High Court rejected application for certificate under Article 133.

anchor.surface_text: An application filed by the petitioner for certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution was rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: Commissioner reported Rs. 12,089/14/6 with interest at 6% per annum from May 14, 1948 due to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that pursuant to the order of the Trial Court a Commissioner was appointed and the Commissioner reported that Rs. 12,089/14/6 with interest at the rate of 6 per annum from May 14, 1948 were due to the petitioner

facts.text: Petitioner conceded that claim in court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded, and in our judgment companynsel is right in so companyceding, that the petitioner companyld number seek a certificate under cl.  a  of Art. 133 1 . The claim in the companyrt of first instance did number Teach Rs. 20,000

facts.text: Petitioner admitted in plaint that bales were sold by respondents as his agents.

anchor.surface_text: It was admitted by the petitioner in his plaint that the bales of companyton were sold by the respondents as his agents.

facts.text: Right of respondents to sell the bales not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The right of the respondents to sell the bales was number in dispute.

facts.text: Judgment of High Court proceeds on appreciation of evidence and findings, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court proceeds entirely upon appre- ciation of evidence and on the findings recorded the petitioners suit must stand dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds petitioner's contentions under Art. 133(1)(b) have no substance.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the companytention raised by the petitioner under either head has numbersubstance.

facts.text: Subject-matter of suit was claim for Rs. 10,665 on dishonoured cheques and balance on accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the suit was, therefore, a claim for Rs. 10,665 due to the petitioner on a cause of action arising on cheques dishonoured and a claim for the balance of the price due as may be ascertained on taking accounts.

facts.text: Counsel for petitioner: Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava, Zalim Singh, Meeratwal and Naunit Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava, Zalim Singh, Meeratwal and Naunit Lal, for the petitioner C. Setalvad, and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: C. Setalvad and I. N. Shroff.

anchor.surface_text: Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava, Zalim Singh, Meeratwal and Naunit Lal, for the petitioner C. Setalvad, and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Petitioner received Rs. 4,000 subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: less Rs. 4,000 subsequently received by him.

The petitioner applies for special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution, against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan dated December 16, 1963 in Civil First Appeal No. 54 of 1956 on two grounds 1 that the judgment of the High Court involves a claim or question respecting property of number less than Rs. 20,000 in value, and the High Court erred in refusing a certificate under Art. 133 1 b of the Constitution

concepts.interpretation: Court entertains the special leave petition but ultimately dismisses it as the case is not fit for appeal.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: a  of Art. 133 1 . The claim in the companyrt of first instance did number Teach Rs. 20,000 and one

anchor.surface_text: An application filed by the petitioner for certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution was rejected by the High Court.

concepts.interpretation: Certificate under cl. (1)(a) not available as the claim in court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ing from companysideration other companyditions number material-a judgment involving directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property

concepts.unlisted_description: Appeal as of right where subject-matter value in court below not less than Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: that the judgment of the High Court involves a claim or question respecting property of number less than Rs. 20,000 in value, and the High Court erred in refusing a certificate under Art. 133 1 b of the Constitution and 2 that the case is otherwise fit for appeal to the Supreme Court.

concepts.interpretation: Requires judgment, decree or final order involving directly or indirectly a claim or question respecting property of amount or value not less than Rs. 20,000, which must be property in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute; distinguishes from cl. (1)(a) where value of subject-matter in court of first instance is decisive.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ditions which attract the application of the two clauses. Under cl.  a  what is decisive is the amount or value of the subject-matter in the companyrt

concepts.unlisted_description: Certificate for appeal where judgment involves property claim/question >= Rs. 20,000 beyond subject-matter.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Rajasthan reversed the decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the suit, holding that the transactions in respect of which the claim was made by the petitioner were those of an unregistered firm constituted by the petitioner and another person named Duli Chand and the suit was barred because the firm was number registered. An application filed by the petitioner for certificate under Art. 133

concepts.unlisted_description: High Court power to grant certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Rajasthan reversed the decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the suit, holding that the transactions in respect of which the claim was made by the petitioner were those of an unregistered firm constituted by the petitioner and another person named Duli Chand and the suit was barred because the firm was number registered.

concepts.interpretation: Suit barred if transactions are of an unregistered firm.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: upon appre- ciation of evidence and on the findings recorded the petitioners suit must stand dismissed. But companynsel for the petitioner urged that

concepts.unlisted_description: Bar on maintaining suit to enforce rights arising from contract of unregistered firm (refers to Indian Partnership Act provision).

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that pursuant to the order of the Trial Court a Commissioner was appointed and the Commissioner reported that Rs. 12,089/14/6 with interest at the rate of 6 per annum from May 14, 1948 were due to the petitioner and as the amount due to the petitioner on that footing was number less than Rs. 20,000 at the date of the decree of the High Court, the judgment of the High Court involved a claim respecting property of that amount or value.

concepts.interpretation: Commissioner's report on amount due does not constitute a separate claim respecting property other than the subject-matter.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: nclude money. But the property respecting which the claim or question arises must be property in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the d

anchor.surface_text: The expression property is number defined in the Code, but having regard to the use of the expression amount it would apparently include money. But the property respecting which the claim or question arises must be property in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute.

concepts.interpretation: Expression 'property' in Art. 133(1)(b) not defined in the Code (CPC) but includes money; must be distinct from subject-matter of suit.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: nt or value of the subject-matter in the companyrt of first instance and still in dispute in appeal to the Supreme Court under cl.  b  it is the amoun

concepts.unlisted_description: Undefined in CPC but interpreted to include money for appeal valuation purposes.

issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court involves a claim or question respecting property of value not less than Rs. 20,000, such that the High Court erred in refusing a certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: that the judgment of the High Court involves a claim or question respecting property of number less than Rs. 20,000 in value, and the High Court erred in refusing a certificate under Art. 133 1 b of the Constitution and 2 that the case is otherwise fit for appeal to the Supreme Court.

issues.text: Whether a certificate under cl. (1)(a) of Art. 133 was available to the petitioner?

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded, and in our judgment counsel is right in so conceding, that the petitioner could not seek a certificate under cl. (1)(a) of Art. 133(1). The claim in the court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000 and one of the conditions for a certificate under that clause being absent, the claim could not be maintained.

issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court involves a question relating to the right of the petitioner respecting 104 bales of cotton belonging to him and sold by the respondents for an amount exceeding Rs. 27,000 qualifying under Art. 133(1)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: This argument is sought to be presented in two ways. It is urged in the first instance that the judgment of the High Court involves a question relating to the right of the petitioner respecting 104 bales of companyton belonging to him and sold by the respondents for an amount exceeding Rs. 27,000.

issues.text: Whether pursuant to the Commissioner's report, the amount due to the petitioner with interest was not less than Rs. 20,000 at the date of the High Court decree, such that the judgment involved a claim respecting property of that value under Art. 133(1)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that pursuant to the order of the Trial Court a Commissioner was appointed and the Commissioner reported that Rs. 12,089/14/6 with interest at the rate of 6 per annum from May 14, 1948 were due to the petitioner and as the amount due to the petitioner on that footing was number less than Rs. 20,000

issues.text: Whether the case is otherwise fit for appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 136?

anchor.surface_text: and 2 that the case is otherwise fit for appeal to the Supreme Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Judgment proceeds on appreciation of evidence and findings, suit stands dismissed.

arguments.claim: Petitioner could not seek certificate under cl. (1)(a) of Art. 133(1) as claim in court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded, and in our judgment counsel is right in so conceding, that the petitioner could not seek a certificate under cl. (a) of Art. 133(1). The claim in the court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000

arguments.claim: Art. 133(1)(b) requires judgment involving claim or question respecting property of >= Rs. 20,000 in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute; cl. (a) concerns subject-matter value in court of first instance.

anchor.surface_text: To attract the application of Art. 133(1)(b) it is essential that there must be... a judgment involving directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property of an amount or value not less that Rs.20,000. The variation in the language

arguments.claim: The subject-matter of the suit was a claim for Rs. 10,665 on dishonoured cheques and balance of price on taking accounts; judgment did not involve additional property >= Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the suit was, therefore, a claim for Rs. 10,665 due to the petitioner on a cause of action arising on cheques dishonoured and a claim for the balance of the price due as may be ascertained on taking accounts.

arguments.claim: Petitioner admitted bales sold by respondents as agents; right to sell not in dispute; dispute is only right to retain price.

anchor.surface_text: It was admitted by the petitioner in his plaint that the bales of cotton were sold by the respondents as his agents. The right of the respondents to sell the bales was not in dispute.

holdings.text: The petitioner could not seek a certificate under cl. (a) of Art. 133(1) as the claim in the court of first instance did not reach Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded, and in our judgment counsel is right in so conceding, that the petitioner could not seek a certificate under cl. a of Art. 133 1 . The claim in the court of first instance did number Teach Rs. 20,000

holdings.reasoning_summary: Straightforward application of valuation threshold in Art. 133(1)(a); conceded by petitioner and affirmed by court.

holdings.text: Under Art. 133(1)(b), the property respecting which the claim or question arises must be in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The expression property is number defined in the Code, but having regard to the use of the expression amount it would apparently include money. But the property respecting which the claim or question arises must be property in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis distinguishing language of cls. (a) and (b); property includes money but must be distinct from suit's subject-matter.

holdings.text: The judgment does not involve a claim or question respecting the 104 bales of cotton under Art. 133(1)(b) as the dispute concerns only the price money retained by agents.

anchor.surface_text: It was admitted by the petitioner in his plaint that the bales of companyton were sold by the respondents as his agents. The right of the respondents to sell the bales was number in dispute. what was challenged was the right of the respondents to retain the price received by them. It cannot be said that a judgment dealing with a claim to money alleged to be due from an agent for price of property belonging to the principal sold by the agent either directly or indirectly involves a claim or question respecting property which is sold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's admission that bales were sold by agents and right to sell undisputed; challenge limited to retention of sale proceeds (money), not the sold property itself.

holdings.text: The Commissioner's report of amount due with interest does not qualify as property under Art. 133(1)(b) as it forms part of the suit's subject-matter.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the alternative ground assist the petitioner. It is true that by his petition the petitioner claims restoration of the decree of the Trial Court, and by adding interest at the rate of 6 per annum to the petitioners claim as awarded under the report of the Commissioner, the claim of the petitioner on appeal exceeds Rs. 20,000. But this is still the subject-matter in dispute the Judgment does number involve any claim or question respecting property in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner's computation relates directly to the balance of sale proceeds claimed in suit; exceeds 20k but remains the core subject-matter, not additional property.

holdings.text: Special leave petition dismissed as High Court judgment rests on appreciation of evidence and factual findings; case not fit for appeal under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court proceeds entirely upon appre- ciation of evidence and on the findings recorded the petitioners suit must stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No substantial question of law; High Court's decision purely factual based on evidence appreciation; no grounds for interference under Art. 136 discretion.

holdings.text: Petitioner's contentions regarding certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) lack substance.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the companytention raised by the petitioner under either head has numbersubstance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of arguments on property valuation under Art. 133(1)(b) after detailed analysis.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the companytention raised by the petitioner under either head has numbersubstance. It is companyceded, and in our judgment companynsel is right in so companyceding, that the petitioner companyld number seek a certificate under cl.  a  of Art. 133 1 . The claim in the companyrt of first instance did number Teach Rs. 20,000 and one of the companyditions for a certificate under that clause being absent, the claim companyld number be maintained. To attract the application of Art. 133 1   b  it is essential that there must be-omitting from companysideration other companyditions number material-a judgment involving directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property of an amount or value number less that Rs.20,000.
